setup.question: How would you describe the tone throughout the passage?
answers: While there was some uncertainty and excitement, it was relatively tranquil throughout.
It went from highly excited to mildly calm.

Text.text:
Give me a story summary please. This one is gonna need a series of pieces of evidence that is well contextualized, and I'm not afraid to keep this debate going 5+ rounds to make sure I'm on the right page here. 

Have fun <3

Unlike our usual sci-fi story, this one's pretty basic. It's about this girl, Peggy, who wants to go to New York for theatre. There's uncertainty because her parents are still deciding whether she can go or not:
and she doesn't know for sure she'll be successful when she gets there. There's excitement because her parents decided to let her go, and even have an old friend who

they're setting her up with

But there's no physical fight scene, no escape to other planets, etc. It really is relatively tranquil throughout

The protagonist Peggy (and her family) is from a small town in Wisconsin and is currently going to college to be a teacher. The passage goes through an argument she has with her parents about wanting to give up school and go to New York to be an actor. After this, while waiting for her parents to discuss it, she is a bit tense/agitated so she goes for a ride on her horse + visit a friend to calm down her nerves. 
The answer is B bc we feel a lot of excitement from Peggy's agitated mental state:

I'd say I'm leaning A a bit right now but I think this whole quote relies on beginning lines.

I'd ask in your next speech both sides provide evidence from the beginning, middle and ending. I might even ask for just for evidence for 2 consecutive speeches. Like a genuine evidence dump.

See that B doesn't provide anything about the tone *becoming* mildly calm

Also, I've proven the UNCERTAINTY of the leaving. If Peggy's parents had always been clear abt her being allowed to go, there wouldn't even be a discussion in the first place

I'd also like to suggest to the judge to not take too many turns bc you want to read the whole story to get the tone.. Conclude from some evidence, don't lose points

As for how excited wanna be actress Peggy gets, she also reasonably bargains
Beginning: Peggy is agitated when arguing with her parents: "
" and "

"

Middle: Her mom actually steps in to initiate the 'bargaining' phase (see quote order). This is where the tone begins to change.
Some evidence of the 'changing' tone is when she starts to take some time to compose herself when continuing the conversation:
And later she goes to the barn to be with her horse, we see that it was her fave place "

" (can add context if needed)

I had to cut some sents short bc of quote limit.

Leaning B - think the first B quote in speech 1 when contrasted with the last big quote from A really make me think the story is about Peggy maturing or maybe just finding less overemotion and allows that shift. I will definitely take another round or two. B should continue to provide evidence in the same format they just used. I would also encourage A to try the same:
1) beginning
2) middle
3) end

ImportantlyI'd like to note PASSAGE tone isn't defined by Peggy alone
Begin: Conversation about decision
Her mom doesNOT initiate bargaining, but her parents do remain chill. Thats Bs misquote, B not doing so for my space limited quotes will mean that mine aren't. Dad chill-
, mom chill-

. Even Peggy isn't throwing fists

MID She leaves kitchen while they make decision
She does go to barn etc but she's still filled with uncertainty and
ENDAfter parents say yes & talk details:
see that she's still excited
Filling out more quotes from the start: (1)

Ugh, yeah I did say mom instead of dad in regards to c.753 but I think the sentiment doesn't change despite this. I think A's quote c.623 basically conveys more info in a similar vein that Peggy's intensity drives the tone in the early part of the passage. 

After she leaves to let her parents think, we get some exposition as "
" and how it was a peaceful small-town life. After c.2421, she visits a friend till her parents decide (c.5143).

I'd like to see A explore the uncertainty aspect of their prompt. I'm less sure exactly what to evaluate though because A brings up the ev that the dad's voice is chill. Leaning 50-50. A also makes a good comeback with their last quote. Will need a B response.

Judge, I'm disappointed that you're still at 50-50. B *clearly doesn't respond to my last Excited quote* and they already had the chance to do so in their last speech! In fact, if you'd been checking the quote panel you'd see that B never brings anything up from the end which clearly EXISTS

Beginning Uncertainty abt her leaving. Parents say

Middle Same Uncertainty, still some Excited literally fighting the impulse to return to kitchen
End Parents mention that they're setting things up at NY but
Uncertainty of success in NY, excited to go
See here that after c.5157, her parents tell her, "
" and

I didn't respond before bc I figured that there is little diff between both options in the expected tone at the end of the passage ('relatively tranquil throughout' vs 'mildly calm'). Imo I need to convey a _change_ in tone whereas A has to prove it is consistent throughout. This is the shift in Peggy towards bargaining. The tone around c.5424 is similar to c.1074 _after_ she begins bargaining and not like c.480 when she is impertinent.

I am leaning A because the contents of the story are very down to earth/slice of life-esque and A makes a good point about uncertainty therefore A makes more sense in that regard. I agree that the ending must be calm because both sides agree. B to comeback you need to prove there's no uncertainty or that the beginning was a way more more calm than the ending.

So B is still only treating the first conversation as the story. It's silly to think that a description of the tone *throughout* the passage is a highly excited Peggy for the first 3 parts, then calm for the rest of the story. Numbers that mark the parts of the story:

As for Peggy's parents telling her to go to sleep... notice how B relents that the parents are chill here & that's how it's tranquil despite Peggy's excitement - a characterization I argued for the first conversation

Plus, I don't have to prove *highly* excited. It's enough that there's some excitement still near end:
. After B's quote
In addition to the para nos. (from A), relevant meta info from the title is the first chapter name of "

" which supports my position of an "exciting" beginning. 
The parts support my argument bc the bargaining phase begins at (4). Till then, Peggy is largely _against_ her parents, and then the tone shifts to be more collaborative/calm. The quotes in order backs this up. 
For lack of uncertainty before (4), what her mom says after c.656 is "
" + her dad says
Seeing this support, she changes her tone at (4)
i really wanna vote but im gonna hold back for one last round. give me anything you got. gonna pull the trigger. don't think i will do any lower than 50-50. Feeling A but this question is tough.

You should go all the way to 99% and end this debate

B is still not responding to there still being Excitement AFTER B says the tone has shifted to calm at (4). Notice all the literal and implicit Excites after that (4) at /889-890/. This is clearly B lying about the plot and being caught in the lie, unable to respond

More proof, playing with B's quote:

See? Part II is still Drama, that's just the normal dramatic framing of wannabe actor Peggy

I could give a bunch more
But there has been plenty of evidence for A. B clearly messed up their dishonest debater narrative
I'll finish up the quotes A has presented to give you the context for these post (4).
and

Again I think the question is asking not of incidents but the passage tone as a whole. It is telling that after all of these moments, they immediately settle down for milk and cookies or plan to pack/go to bed. It's a classic American house setting and the shift from arguing to bargaining is the focus of the question here. I disagree that it's super clear-cut but B fits better given the quotes.

Taking a risk because this debate has gone forever. I agree A has been proven more than B but without seeing the whole story its hard to conclude A super confidently. Pretty sure if I'm wrong on this im blaming the question lol because absent a few lines of loud emotion from Peggy in the very beginning everyone else is chill.
very subjective, seems like it'll be a long debate
A seems to be a meta arg, while B is more factual. Main prob I have with me is that its very subjective - I'm not ness excited just bc mc is?
honestly I buy A's meta arg from first round - B hasn't proved that there is a "high" level of excitement.

answers.reason for outcome: Didn't really have too much to latch onto, I thought I started out well trying to confuse the judge but as the number of turns increased, I ran out of quotes I could come up with while the honest debater could keep presenting more. I'm glad I didn't get shut-out honestly.
honestly I buy A's meta arg from first round - B hasn't proved that there is a "high" level of excitement. I think that B needed to meet a higher level of proof that they just don't.
Evidence and reasoning. But I think the judge could've ended with higher confidence / in less rounds
